yet.\n\nThe question it does raise for today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting is whether the moderation influences some officials to reduce a prior estimate of three cuts for the rest of 2024 {"uri": "2024-06-387535789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:35:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:35:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:16:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/newsfront/federal-reserve-inflation-interest-rates/2024/06/12/id/1168494/", "title": "Fed Sees Some Strides on Inflation, Just One Cut in 2024", "body": "Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)\n\nFederal Reserve officials said Wednesday inflation has fallen further toward their target in recent months but signaled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year.\n\nThe policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three, likely because inflation remains persistently elevated.\n\nIn a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said that the economy is growing at a solid pace while hiring has \"remained strong.\" The Fed also said that in recent months there has been \"modest further progress\" toward its 2% inflation target. That is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting May 1, when the officials said there \"has been a lack of further progress\" on inflation.\n\nThe policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged at roughly 5.3%. The benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation. Fed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, auto loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing.\n\nThe Fed's rate cut forecasts reflect separate estimates from 19 different policymakers. The Fed said that 8 of those officials projected two cuts, 7 projected one, and four said they expect no cuts at all this year.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts were likely influenced by the government's May inflation data, released Wednesday morning. That report showed that inflation cooled unexpectedly. Overall prices were unchanged from April to May. And so-called core prices, which exclude volatile food and energy costs, rose just 0.2%, the smallest monthly rise since October.\n\nMeasured from a year earlier, consumer prices rose 3.3% in May, down from 3.4% the previous month. Year-over-year core inflation slowed from 3.6% in April to 3.4% in May, the mildest annual pace in three years.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the past three to four years.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsMax"}, "authors": [{"uri": "christopher_rugaber@newsmax.com", "name": "Christopher Rugaber", "type": {"uri": "2024-06-386934859", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "09:17:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T09:17:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T08:54:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.news18.com/business/us-federal-reserve-decision-to-be-out-today-check-india-timing-whats-expected-8930171.html", "title": "US Federal Reserve Decision To Be Out Today: Check India Timing, What's Expected?", "body": "US Fed Chair Powell will announce the interest rate decision at 2:00 pm ET (or 11:30 pm as per Indian time), to be followed by his press conference\n\nThe US Federal Reserve is going to conclude the two-day meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on June 12. US Fed Chair Powell will announce the interest rate decision at 2:00 pm ET (or 11:30 pm as per Indian time), to be followed by his press conference. Investors are keenly looking for any indication of the timeline for the rate cuts.\n\nThe market is divided on whether the US Fed would cut rates once or twice this year after a strong US labour report. So, the attention will be on policymakers' updated economic projections and Chair Jerome Powell's press conference.\n\nUS Fed Meeting: Key Things to Watch Out For\n\nIt is also to be seen whether Powell's tone will continue to be hawkish or shift to be a dovish one. Investors also await the 'dot plot' in today's Summary of Economic Projections.\n\nSuman Bannerjee, CIO of Hedonova, said, \"The upcoming Fed meeting is crucial as it will likely maintain the fed funds rate target range of 5.25% to 5.5%, its highest since 2001, amidst efforts to control inflation without triggering a recession. Key aspects include updates on the pace of balance sheet runoff and economic projections, particularly for GDP growth, unemployment, and inflation.\"\n\nInvestors will scrutinize the Fed's stance on future rate cuts, especially given mixed inflation data and economic slowdown signs. The May jobs report and upcoming inflation data will also heavily influence the Fed's decisions and economic outlook, he added.\n\nWhen to Expect the Start of the Fed Rate Cut Cycle\n\nAccording to the bond market, investors are potentially anticipating the first Fed rate cut at the September 2024 meeting, with a 47.6% probability. The likelihood of at least two rate cuts by the end of the year is also significant, at 36.9%. However, this timeline is contingent on continued positive inflation data and economic conditions. Persistent sticky inflation and economic growth indicators will play a crucial role in determining the exact timing of rate cuts, with the Fed needing to balance inflation control with economic stability.\n\nUS Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will also likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2 per cent target, they are downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate just once or twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data being released in the morning. The inflation report is expected to show that consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- so-called core inflation -- rose 0.3% from April to May. That would be the same as in the previous month and higher than Fed officials would prefer to see.\n\nOverall inflation, held down by falling gas prices, is thought to have edged up just 0.1%. Measured from a year earlier, consumer prices are projected to have risen 3.4% in May, the same as in April.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the {"uri": "8174748984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:13:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:13:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:11:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.wivb.com/news/national/watch-live-fed-chair-jerome-powell-discusses-latest-economic-projections-expectation-of-a-single-rate-cut-this-year/", "title": "WATCH LIVE: Fed Chair Jerome Powell discusses latest economic projections, expectation of a single rate cut this year", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve officials said Wednesday that inflation has fallen further toward their target in recent months but signaled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year.\n\nThe policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three, likely because inflation remains persistently elevated.\n\nIn a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said that the economy is growing at a solid pace while hiring has \"remained strong.\" The Fed also said that in recent months there has been \"modest further progress\" toward its 2% inflation target. That is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting May 1, when the officials said there \"has been a lack of further progress\" on inflation.\n\nThe policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged at roughly 5.3%. The benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation. Fed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, auto loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing.\n\nThe Fed's rate cut forecasts reflect separate estimates from 19 different policymakers. The Fed said that 8 of those officials projected two cuts, 7 projected one, and four said they expect no cuts at all this year.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2% target, they're downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data, released Wednesday morning. That report showed that inflation cooled unexpectedly. Overall prices were unchanged from April to May. And so-called core prices, which exclude volatile food and energy costs, rose just 0.2%, the smallest monthly rise since October.\n\nMeasured from a year earlier, consumer prices rose 3.3% in May, down from 3.4% the previous month. Year-over-year core inflation slowed from 3.6% in April to 3.4% in May, the mildest annual pace in three years.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the past three to four years.", "source": {"uri": "wivb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "wivb4"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interest_rate", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-06-387533936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:33:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:33:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:29:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://wgntv.com/news/watch-live-fed-chair-jerome-powell-discusses-latest-economic-projections-expectation-of-a-single-rate-cut-this-year/", "title": "WATCH LIVE: Fed Chair Jerome Powell discusses latest economic projections, expectation of a single rate cut this year", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve officials said Wednesday that inflation has fallen further toward their target level in recent months but signaled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year.\n\nThe policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three, likely because inflation, despite having cooled in the past two months, remains persistently elevated.\n\nIn a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said the economy is growing at a solid pace while hiring has \"remained strong.\" The officials also noted that in recent months there has been \"modest further progress\" toward its 2% inflation target. That is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting May 1, when the officials had said there had been \"a lack of further progress\" on inflation.\n\nThe policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged Wednesday at roughly 5.3%. The benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation. Fed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, auto loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing.\n\nThe officials' rate-cut forecast reflects the individual estimates of 19 policymakers. The Fed said that eight of those officials projected two rate cuts and seven projected one cut. Four said they envisioned no cuts at all this year.\n\nThe Fed's updated quarterly projections are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the government reported that inflation eased in May for a second straight month, a hopeful sign that an acceleration of prices that occurred early this year may have passed. Consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- the closely watched \"core\" index -- rose just 0.2% from April, the smallest rise since October. Measured from a year earlier, core prices climbed 3.4%, the mildest pace in three years.\n\nThough inflation has tumbled from a peak of 9.1% two years ago, it remains too high for the Fed's liking. The policymakers now face the delicate task of keeping rates high enough to slow spending and defeat high inflation without derailing the economy.\n\nThe central bank's rate policies over the next several months could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had cooled steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a rare \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. But inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. {"uri": "2024-06-387108724", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "11:43:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T11:43:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T06:22:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.weareiowa.com/article/news/nation-world/federal-reserve-no-rate-cuts/507-92e623fc-93b3-4030-9ce8-66d05f236de4", "title": "Federal Reserve is likely to scale back plans for rate cuts because of persistent inflation", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2% target, they are downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate just once or twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data being released in the morning. The inflation report is expected to show that consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- so-called core inflation -- rose 0.3% from April to May. That would be the same as in the previous month and higher than Fed officials would prefer to see.\n\nOverall inflation, held down by falling gas prices, is thought to have edged up just 0.1%. Measured from a year earlier, consumer prices are projected to have risen 3.4% in May, the same as in April.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the {"uri": "8174336728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "13:25:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T13:25:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T13:24:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/watch-live-fed-chair-powell-speaks-after-june-interest-rate-decision", "title": "WATCH LIVE: Fed chair Powell speaks after June interest rate decision", "body": "Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will speak to the media on Wednesday after fed officials make an announcement on interest rate cuts.\n\nThe event is scheduled to begin at 2:30 p.m. ET. Watch in the player above.\n\nThey are likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2% target, they are downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate just once or twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data being released in the morning. The inflation report is expected to show that consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- so-called core inflation -- rose 0.3% from April to May. That would be the same as in the previous month and higher than Fed officials would prefer to see.\n\nOverall inflation, held down by falling gas prices, is thought to have edged up just 0.1%. Measured from a year earlier, consumer prices are projected to have risen 3.4% in May, the same as in April.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the past three to four years.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4 percent, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data being released in the morning. The inflation report is expected to show that consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- so-called core inflation -- rose 0.3 percent from April to May. That would be the same as in the previous month and higher than Fed officials would prefer to see.\n\nOverall inflation, held down by falling gas prices, is thought to have edged up just 0.1 percent. Measured from a year earlier, consumer prices are projected to have risen 3.4 percent in May, the same as in April.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2 percent or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief US economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the {"uri": "2024-06-386807722", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "07:19:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T07:19:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-11T17:58:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-06-12/federal-reserve-is-likely-to-scale-back-plans-for-rate-cuts-because-of-persistent-inflation", "title": "Federal Reserve Is Likely to Scale Back Plans for Rate Cuts Because of Persistent Inflation", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2% target, they are downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate just once or twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data being released in the morning. The inflation report is expected to show that consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- so-called core inflation -- rose 0.3% from April to May. That would be the same as in the previous month and higher than Fed officials would prefer to see.\n\nOverall inflation, held down by falling gas prices, is thought to have edged up just 0.1%. Measured from a year earlier, consumer prices are projected to have risen 3.4% in May, the same as in April.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the past three to four years.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-386835275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "07:47:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T07:47:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T07:00:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/federal-reserve-is-likely-to-scale-back-plans-for-rate-cuts-because-of-persistent-inflation/article_df1e54d6-9e5d-5654-a36b-05ecc577ca82.html", "title": "Federal Reserve is likely to scale back plans for rate cuts because of persistent inflation", "body": "FILE - Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference at the Federal Reserve in Washington, May 1, 2024. On Wednesday, June 12, 2024, the Federal Reserve ends its latest meeting by issuing a policy statement, updating its economic and interest-rate projections and holding a news conference with Powell.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2% target, they are downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate just once or twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data being released in the morning. The inflation report is expected to show that consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- so-called core inflation -- rose 0.3% from April to May. That would be the same as in the previous month and higher than Fed officials would prefer to see.\n\nOverall inflation, held down by falling gas prices, is thought to have edged up just 0.1%. Measured from a year earlier, consumer prices are projected to have risen 3.4% in May, the same as in April.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the past three to four years.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "christopher_rugaber@register-herald.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-06-387528184", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:26:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:26:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:01:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://pbn.com/federal-reserve-is-likely-to-scale-back-plans-for-rate-cuts-because-of-still-elevated-inflation/", "title": "Federal Reserve sees some progress on inflation but envisions just one rate cut this year", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal Reserve officials said Wednesday that inflation has fallen further toward their target level in recent months but signaled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year. The policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three, likely because inflation, despite having cooled in the past two months, remains persistently elevated. In a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said the economy is growing at a solid pace while hiring has \"remained strong.\" The officials also noted that in recent months there has been \"modest further progress\" toward its 2% inflation target. That is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting May 1, when the officials had said there had been \"a lack of further progress\" on inflation. The policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged Wednesday at roughly 5.3%. The benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation. Fed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, auto loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing. The officials' rate-cut forecast reflects the individual estimates of 19 policymakers. The Fed said that eight of those officials projected two rate cuts and seven projected one cut. Four said they envisioned no cuts at all this year. The Fed's updated quarterly projections are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts - or hikes - depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time. On Wednesday morning, the government reported that inflation eased in May for a second straight month, a hopeful sign that an acceleration of prices that occurred early this year may have passed. Consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs - the closely watched \"core\" index - rose just 0.2% from April, the smallest rise since October. Measured from a year earlier, core prices climbed 3.4%, the mildest pace in three years. Though inflation has tumbled from a peak of 9.1% two years ago, it remains too high for the Fed's liking. The policymakers now face the delicate task of keeping rates high enough to slow spending and defeat high inflation without derailing the economy. The central bank's rate policies over the next several months could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden. Inflation had cooled steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a rare \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. But inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing. In early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought. Last month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month. (UPDATE: Story recast with release of quarterly forecast)", "source": {"uri": "pbn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Providence Business News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbn.com", {"uri": "8174841176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "19:33:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T19:33:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T19:32:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/money/2024/06/12/federal-reserve-powell-inflation-interest-rate-cut-economy", "title": "Federal Reserve sees some progress on inflation but envisions just one rate cut this year", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Federal Reserve officials said Wednesday that inflation has fallen further toward their target level in recent months but signaled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year.\n\nThe policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three because inflation, despite having cooled in the past two months, remains persistently elevated.\n\nIn a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said the economy is growing at a solid pace, while hiring has \"remained strong.\" The officials also noted that in recent months there has been \"modest\" further progress toward their 2% inflation target. That is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting May 1, when the officials had noted a lack of progress.\n\nStill, the central bank made clear Wednesday that further improvement is needed.\n\n\"We'll need to see more good data to bolster our confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward 2%,\" Chair Jerome Powell said at a news conference after the Fed meeting ended.\n\nThe policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged at roughly 5.3%. The benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation. Fed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, auto loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing.\n\nThe officials' rate-cut forecast reflects the individual estimates of 19 policymakers. The Fed said eight of the officials projected two rate cuts. Seven projected one cut. Four of the policymakers envisioned no cuts at all this year.\n\n\"What everyone agrees on,\" Powell said, is that the Fed's timetable for rate cuts is \"going to be data-dependent.\"\n\nThe Fed's latest projections are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation evolve over time.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the government reported that inflation eased in May for a second straight month, a hopeful sign that an acceleration of prices that occurred early this year may have passed. Consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- the closely watched \"core\" index -- rose just 0.2% from April, the smallest rise since October. Measured from a year earlier, core prices climbed 3.4%, the mildest pace in three years.\n\n\"We welcome today's reading and hope for more like that,\" Powell said.\n\nStock prices jumped and bond yields fell Wednesday morning after the government reported the milder-than-expected inflation data -- and didn't budge much even after the Fed's policymakers projected fewer rate cuts for 2024 than the market had expected.\n\nThough inflation has tumbled from a peak of 9.1% two years ago, it remains too high for the Fed's liking. The policymakers now face the delicate task of keeping rates high enough to slow spending and defeat high inflation without derailing the economy.\n\nThe central bank's rate policies over the next several months could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had cooled steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a rare \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. But inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nAsked at his news conference about the eventual need for rate cuts, Powell said, \"We think ultimately if you set (interest rate) policy at the restrictive level, eventually you will see real weakening in the economy.\"\n\nThough the economy has managed to keep growing despite the high rates the central bank has engineered, the Fed chair said that \"ultimately, we think rates will have to come down to continue to support that. So far, they haven't had to.\"\n\nAs part of the updated quarterly forecasts the policymakers issued Wednesday, they projected that the economy will grow 2.1% this year and 2% in 2025, the same as they had envisioned in March. They expect core inflation to be 2.8% by year's end, according to their preferred gauge, up from a previous forecast of 2.6%. And they project that unemployment will stay at its current 4% rate by the end of this year and edge up to 4.2% by the end of 2025.\n\nThe expectation that the unemployment rate will remain around those low levels indicates that the officials believe that while the job market will gradually slow, it will remain fundamentally healthy.\n\n\"By so many measures,\" Powell said, \"the labor market was kind of overheated two years ago, and we've seen it move back into much better balance between supply and demand.\"", "source": {"uri": "chicago.suntimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-06-387299863", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "14:31:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T14:31:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T12:32:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.bostonherald.com/2024/06/12/us-inflation-cooled-in-may-in-sign-that-price-pressures-may-be-easing/", "title": "Federal Reserve is likely to scale back plans for rate cuts because of still-elevated inflation", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2% target, they're downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data, released Wednesday morning. That report showed that inflation cooled unexpectedly. Overall prices were unchanged from April to May. And so-called core prices, which exclude volatile food and energy costs, rose just 0.2%, the smallest monthly rise since October.\n\nMeasured from a year earlier, consumer prices rose 3.3% in May, down from 3.4% the previous month. Year-over-year core inflation slowed from 3.6% in April to 3.4% in May, the mildest annual pace in three years.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the past three to four years.", "source": {"uri": "bostonherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Boston Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@bostonherald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13523531/Federal-Reserve-sees-progress-inflation-signals-just-one-rate-cut-2024.html", "title": "Federal Reserve sees progress on inflation but signals just one...", "body": "The US Federal Reserve officials said that inflation has fallen further towards their target level in recent months but signalled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year.\n\nThe policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three, probably because inflation, despite having cooled in the past two months, remains persistently elevated.\n\nIn a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said the economy is growing at a solid pace, while hiring has \"remained strong\".\n\nThe officials also noted that in recent months there has been \"modest further progress\" towards its 2% inflation target.\n\nWe'll need to see more good data to bolster our confidence that inflation is moving sustainably towards 2% Jerome Powell, Federal Reserve chairman\n\nThat is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting on May 1, when the officials said there had been \"a lack of further progress\" on inflation.\n\nStill, the central bank made clear on Wednesday that further improvement is needed.\n\n\"We'll need to see more good data to bolster our confidence that inflation is moving sustainably towards 2%,\" chairman Jerome Powell said at a news conference after the Fed meeting.\n\nThe policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged at roughly 5.3%.\n\nThe benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation.\n\nFed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, car loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing.\n\nThe officials' rate-cut forecast reflects the individual estimates of 19 policymakers. The Fed said that eight of those officials projected two rate cuts and seven projected one cut. Four said they envisioned no cuts at all this year.\n\nFederal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell (Susan Walsh/AP)\n\nThe Fed's updated quarterly projections are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts - or hikes - depending on how economic growth and inflation evolve over time.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the government reported that inflation eased in May for a second straight month, a hopeful sign that an acceleration of prices that occurred earlier this year may have passed.\n\nConsumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs - the closely watched \"core\" index - rose just 0.2% from April, the smallest rise since October. Measured from a year earlier, core prices climbed 3.4%, the mildest pace in three years.\n\nThough inflation has tumbled from a peak of 9.1% two years ago, it remains too high for the Fed's liking. The policymakers now face the delicate task of keeping rates high enough to slow spending and defeat high inflation without derailing the economy.\n\nThe central bank's rate policies over the next several months could also have consequences for the presidential race.\n\nThough the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that is because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had cooled steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a rare \"soft landing\", whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperilling a soft landing.\n\nAs part of the updated quarterly forecasts the Fed's policymakers issued on Wednesday, they projected that the economy will grow 2.1% this year and 2% in 2025, the same as they had envisioned in March.\n\nThey expect core inflation to be 2.8% by the year's end, according to their preferred gauge, up from a previous forecast of 2.6%. And they project that unemployment will stay at its current 4% rate by the end of this year and edge up to 4.2% by the end of 2025.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": That is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting May 1, when the officials had said there had been \"a lack of further progress\" on inflation.\n\nThe policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged Wednesday at roughly 5.3%. The benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation. Fed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, auto loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing.\n\nThe officials' rate-cut forecast reflects the individual estimates of 19 policymakers. {"uri": "8174780070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:38:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:38:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:37:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/06/11/federal-reserve-sees-some-progress-on-inflation-but-envisions-just-one-rate-cut-this-year/", "title": "Federal Reserve sees some progress on inflation but envisions just one rate cut this year", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve officials said Wednesday that inflation has fallen further toward their target level in recent months but signaled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year.\n\nThe policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three, likely because inflation, despite having cooled in the past two months, remains persistently elevated.\n\nIn a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said the economy is growing at a solid pace, while hiring has \"remained strong.\" The officials also noted that in recent months there has been \"modest further progress\" toward its 2% inflation target. That is a more positive assessment than after the Fed's previous meeting May 1, when the officials said there had been \"a lack of further progress\" on inflation.\n\nThe policymakers, as expected, kept their key rate unchanged at roughly 5.3%. The benchmark rate has remained at that level since July of last year, after the Fed raised it 11 times to try to slow borrowing and spending and cool inflation. Fed rate cuts would, over time, lighten loan costs for consumers, who have faced punishingly high rates for mortgages, auto loans, credit cards and other forms of borrowing.\n\nThe officials' rate-cut forecast reflects the individual estimates of 19 policymakers. The Fed said that eight of those officials projected two rate cuts and seven projected one cut. Four said they envisioned no cuts at all this year.\n\nThe Fed's updated quarterly projections are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation evolve over time.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the government reported that inflation eased in May for a second straight month, a hopeful sign that an acceleration of prices that occurred early this year may have passed. Consumer prices excluding volatile food and energy costs -- the closely watched \"core\" index -- rose just 0.2% from April, the smallest rise since October. Measured from a year earlier, core prices climbed 3.4%, the mildest pace in three years.\n\nThough inflation has tumbled from a peak of 9.1% two years ago, it remains too high for the Fed's liking. The policymakers now face the delicate task of keeping rates high enough to slow spending and defeat high inflation without derailing the economy.\n\nThe central bank's rate policies over the next several months could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had cooled steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a rare \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. But inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nAs part of the updated quarterly forecasts the Fed's policymakers issued Wednesday, they projected that the economy will grow 2.1% this year and 2% in 2025, the same as they had envisioned in March. They expect core inflation to be 2.8% by year's end, according to their preferred gauge, up from a previous forecast of 2.6%. And they project that unemployment will stay at its current 4% rate by the end of this year and edge up to 4.2% by the end of 2025.", "source": {"uri": "trentonian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Trentonian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@trentonian.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8174431486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "14:25:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T14:25:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T14:24:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/federal-reserve-is-likely-to-scale-back-plans-for-rate-cuts-because-of-still-elevated-inflation/", "title": "Federal Reserve is likely to scale back plans for rate cuts because of still-elevated inflation - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will likely make official what's been clear for many weeks: With inflation sticking at a level above their 2% target, they're downgrading their outlook for interest rate cuts.\n\nIn a set of quarterly economic forecasts they will issue after their latest meeting ends, the policymakers are expected to project that they will cut their benchmark rate twice by year's end, rather than the three times they had envisioned in March.\n\nThe Fed's updated economic forecasts, which it will issue Wednesday afternoon, will likely be influenced by the government's May inflation data, released Wednesday morning. That report showed that inflation cooled unexpectedly. Overall prices were unchanged from April to May. And so-called core prices, which exclude volatile food and energy costs, rose just 0.2%, the smallest monthly rise since October.\n\nMeasured from a year earlier, consumer prices rose 3.3% in May, down from 3.4% the previous month. Year-over-year core inflation slowed from 3.6% in April to 3.4% in May, the mildest annual pace in three years.\n\nThe Fed's rate policies typically have a significant impact on the costs of mortgages, auto loans, credit card rates and other forms of consumer and business borrowing. The downgrade in their outlook for rate cuts would mean that such borrowing costs would likely stay higher for longer, a disappointment for potential homebuyers and others.\n\nStill, the Fed's quarterly projections of future interest rate cuts are by no means fixed in time. The policymakers frequently revise their plans for rate cuts -- or hikes -- depending on how economic growth and inflation measures evolve over time.\n\nBut if borrowing costs remain high in the coming months, they could also have consequences for the presidential race. Though the unemployment rate is a low 4%, hiring is robust and consumers continue to spend, voters have taken a generally sour view of the economy under President Joe Biden. In large part, that's because prices remain much higher than they were before the pandemic struck. High borrowing rates impose a further financial burden.\n\nInflation had fallen steadily in the second half of last year, raising hopes that the Fed could achieve a \"soft landing,\" whereby it would manage to conquer inflation through rate hikes without causing a recession. Such an outcome is difficult and rare.\n\nBut inflation came in unexpectedly high in the first three months of this year, delaying hoped-for Fed rate cuts and potentially imperiling a soft landing.\n\nIn early May, Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank needed more confidence that inflation was returning to its target before it would reduce its benchmark rate. Powell noted that it would likely take more time to gain that confidence than Fed officials had previously thought.\n\nLast month, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed's Board of Governors, said he needed to see \"several more months of good inflation data\" before he would consider supporting rate cuts. Though Waller didn't spell out what would constitute good data, economists think it would have to be core inflation of 0.2% or less each month.\n\nPowell and other Fed policymakers have also said that as long as the economy stays healthy, they see no need to cut rates soon.\n\n\"Fed officials have clearly signaled that they are in a wait-and-see mode with respect to the timing and magnitude of rate cuts,\" Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, said in a note to clients.\n\nThe Fed's approach to its rate policies relies heavily on the latest turn in economic data. In the past, the central bank would have put more weight on where it envisioned inflation and economic growth in the coming months.\n\nYet now, \"they don't have any confidence in their ability to forecast inflation,\" said Nathan Sheets, chief global economist at Citi and a former top economist at the Fed.\n\n\"No one,\" Sheets said, \"has been successful at forecasting inflation\" for the past three to four years.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
