This rate has been maintained to help temper consumer demand and manage inflation, which, while decreasing, remains above the Fed's long-term target of 2%.\n\nThe Federal Reserve expressed that economic activity continues to grow at a strong pace, with ongoing job gains and a low unemployment rate. However, the central bank emphasized the need for further evidence of sustained inflation reduction before considering rate cuts.\n\nJerome Powell and other Fed officials have indicated a careful approach, focusing on long-term economic stability rather than immediate rate reductions.\n\nEconomic Indicators and Analyst Perspectives\n\nThe recent Bureau of Labor Statistics report highlighted that the annual inflation rate dropped to 3.3% in May, marking a decline from previous months and a sign of potential stabilization in the economy. {"uri": "2024-06-386819146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "07:32:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T07:32:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T07:09:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240612-us-inflation-data-unlikely-to-alter-fed-plans-to-hold-rates-steady", "title": "US inflation data unlikely to alter Fed plans to hold rates steady", "body": "Washington (AFP) - Fresh US consumer inflation data published Wednesday is unlikely to sway the Federal Reserve, which is widely expected to leave its key lending rate unchanged and lower the number of cuts it has penciled in for this year.\n\nThe May headline consumer inflation rate is expected to be little changed from a month earlier, according to the median forecast of economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.\n\nIf the analysts are correct, inflation will remain stuck firmly above the Fed's long-term target of two percent, giving the US central bank an additional incentive to hold rates at a 23-year high of between 5.25 and 5.50 percent, and wait for the economic winds to change.\n\n\"We expect guidance from the Fed to signal a prolonged pause as the bar for hikes or several cuts remains high,\" Bank of America economists wrote in a recent investor note.\n\nPushing back the cuts\n\nThe US Fed has a dual mandate from Congress to tackle both inflation and unemployment, and the data suggests it remains broadly on track to tackle both without pushing the US into recession -- despite the small uptick in headline inflation in the first few months of this year.\n\nWith cuts almost certainly off the agenda for this meeting, Wednesday's action is likely to center around the economic forecasts from the 19 members of the Fed's rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), which will be updated for the first time since March.\n\nAnalysts are looking to FOMC members to lower their individual forecasts for where rates will be at the end of the year in a chart known as the \"dot plot,\" which reduces the median number of projected cuts this year from three down to two or fewer.\n\n\"We continue to expect the first rate cut in September,\" Goldman Sachs chief economist David Mericle wrote in a note to clients published on Sunday.\n\nHis team at Goldman sees the Fed moving to ease monetary policy every quarter after that, meaning a total of two 0.25-percentage-point cuts in 2024, and four in 2025.\n\n\"It only takes one dot moving higher to shift the median up to two 25bp (basis point) cuts -- which is our base case,\" economists at Citi wrote in a recent investor note.\n\n\"We'd be surprised to see the Fed drop two easings, but it's possible,\" economists at Pantheon Macroeconomics wrote in a note to clients on Tuesday, while also predicting the FOMC will forecast a median of two cuts this year.\n\nOther analysts, including economists at EY and Barclays, expect the updated forecasts to show a median figure of just one rate cut for 2024.\n\n\"We anticipate the dot plot of median rate expectations will feature only one 25 basis points (bps) rate cut in 2024,\" EY chief economist Gregory Daco wrote in a note to clients.\n\nSignificant shift\n\nIf the forecasts were to show just one cut this year, it would mark a significant shift from December, when inflation appeared to be firmly on the path towards two percent, and the financial markets were preparing for as many as six rate cuts this year.\n\nBy contrast, futures traders currently assign a probability of just over 50 percent that the Fed will make its first rate cut by September, although they see November as much more likely, according to data from CME Group.\n\nShortly after the interest rate decision is announced, Fed chair Jerome Powell will take questions from reporters during a press conference in Washington.\n\nPowell has insisted in past public comments that the FOMC will remain \"data-dependent\" in its decision-making, and will not be swayed by politics.\n\nNevertheless, a September start to rate cuts would almost certainly thrust the Fed into the middle of a fractious presidential campaign between President Joe Biden and his Republican opponent, Donald Trump, who has repeatedly questioned the US central bank's independence.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8174759914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:21:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:21:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:19:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/companies/news/fed-officials-dial-back-rate-forecasts-signal-just-one-24-cut-11718216311998.html", "title": "Fed Officials Dial Back Rate Forecasts, Signal Just One '24 Cut", "body": "Officials voted unanimously to keep the benchmark federal funds rate in a range of 5.25% to 5.5% -- a two-decade high first reached in July. But policymakers signaled they now expect to cut rates only once this year, compared to the three reductions forecast in March, according to the median projection.\n\nThey now see four cuts in 2025, more than the three previously outlined.\n\nFollow the reaction in real time on Bloomberg's TOPLive blog\n\nIndividual officials' views on the best path forward for borrowing costs, however, differed. The Fed's \"dot plot\" showed four policymakers saw no cuts this year, while seven anticipated just one reduction and eight expected two cuts.\n\nThe Federal Open Market Committee adjusted language in its post-meeting statement released Wednesday, noting there has been \"modest further progress toward the committee's 2% inflation objective\" in recent months. Previously, the statement pointed to a \"lack\" of further progress.\n\nThe change nods to more current data showing that price growth ebbed in April and May.\n\nChair Jerome Powell will hold a press conference with reporters at 2:30 p.m. following the conclusion of a two-day meeting in Washington.\n\nFed officials have repeatedly said interest rates are likely to stay elevated for longer after price pressures picked up in the first quarter.\n\nData released earlier Wednesday offered some reassurance that progress toward their 2% inflation target has resumed. The so-called core consumer price index, which excludes food and energy, rose 0.2% in May and 3.4% from a year earlier, the slowest pace since 2021.\n\nBefore the decision, investors were betting the Fed would cut rates twice by year end, and saw a high likelihood of a first cut as soon as September, according to futures contracts. Other countries have already begun to lower borrowing costs. The European Central Bank cut interest rates last week, as did the Bank of Canada.\n\nFed officials also published fresh forecasts for inflation, raising their projection for underlying inflation to 2.8% from 2.6% in March.\n\nThey maintained their forecasts for economic growth and the unemployment rate at 2.1% and 4% respectively. The unemployment rate climbed to 4% in May.\n\nRestrictiveness Debate\n\nOfficials also raised their projections for where interest rates will settle in the longer term, to 2.8% from 2.6% at the March gathering. The increase, following a slight bump in March, hints policymakers expect higher interest rates are here to stay.\n\nSome officials, including Dallas Fed President Lorie Logan, have said higher borrowing costs may not be slowing the economy as much as previously thought. Still others, such as New York Fed President John Williams, have said that policy is well positioned to bring inflation down to the Fed's goal.\n\nUS central bankers are engaging in a broader discussion about whether the neutral rate, or the rate at which the Fed is neither slowing nor stimulating the economy, has risen since before the pandemic. A higher neutral rate would suggest that monetary policy is not doing as much to restrain the economy.\n\nWhile US economic growth is moderating and spending is cooling, some aspects of the economy are proving more resilient to higher borrowing costs.\n\nUS nonfarm payrolls surged by 272,000 in May, surpassing all projections in a Bloomberg survey of economists, and average hourly earnings growth picked up.\n\nThe unemployment rate -- which is derived from a separate survey -- increased to 4% from 3.9%, rising to that level for the first time in over two years.\n\nThe Fed also said it would continue to shrink its balance sheet at the slower pace announced in May. Starting this month, the central bank will let its holdings of Treasury securities fall by up to $25 billion a month, down from the previous cap of $60 billion. The cap for mortgage-backed securities was left unchanged at $35 billion.\n\n--With assistance from Kristy Scheuble and Matthew Boesler.\n\n3.6 Crore Indians visited in a single day choosing us as India's undisputed platform for General Election Results. {"uri": "8174853441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "19:46:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T19:46:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T19:44:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/fed-chair-says-figures-have-not-given-confidence-so-far-this-year-for-rate-cuts/3248290", "title": "Fed Chair says figures have not given confidence so far this year for rate cuts", "body": "ISTANBUL (AA) - US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said Wednesday that macroeconomic data have not given Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) members confidence this year to begin rate cuts.\n\n\"The most recent inflation readings have been more favorable than earlier in the year, however, there has been modest progress toward our inflation objective,\" Powell said at a news conference after the Fed's two-day meeting concluded.\n\n\"We need to see more good data to bolster our confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward 2%,\" he added.\n\nPowell said inflation data from earlier this year were higher than expected, although more recent monthly readings have \"eased somewhat.\"\n\n\"Inflation has eased substantially from a peak of 7% to 2.7%, but it is still too high,\" he said. \"We are maintaining our restrictive stance of monetary policy in order to keep demand in line with supply, and reduce inflationary pressures.\"\n\nThe Fed chair said the labor market has come into a better balance with continued strong job gains and a low unemployment rate.\n\n\"As labor market tightness has eased and inflation has declined over the past year, the risks of reaching unemployment and inflation goals have moved towards better balance,\" he said. \"Our economy has made considerable progress towards both goals of maintaining maximum employment and stable prices.\"\n\nHe said economic activity continued to expand at a solid pace, although GDP growth moderated from 3.4% in the fourth quarter last year to 1.3% in the first quarter this year.\n\nPowell noted that the economic outlook remains uncertain, while FOMC members remain highly attentive to inflation risks.\n\n\"We know reducing policy rate too soon, or too much, could result in a reversal of the progress we have seen on inflation. At the same time, reducing policy rate too late or too little could unduly weaken economic activity and employment,\" he said.\n\n\"If the economy remains solid and inflation persists, we are prepared to maintain the current target range for the federal funds rate as long as appropriate,\" he added.\n\nThe comments came after the Fed kept its federal funds rate unchanged between the 5.25% - 5.5% target range, as widely expected, which is the highest in 23 years.\n\nThe central bank, however, signaled it expects one interest rate cut this year, according to its projection materials that were {"uri": "8174436321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "14:29:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T14:29:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T14:28:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/us-consumer-inflation-falls-ahead-of-fed-interest-rate-decision/", "title": "US consumer inflation falls ahead of Fed interest rate decision | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "Fresh US consumer inflation data published Wednesday is unlikely to sway the Federal Reserve's plans to leave its key lending rate unchanged, but could alter how many rate cuts policymakers pencil in for this year.\n\nThe annual consumer price index (CPI) came in at 3.3 percent in May, down 0.1 percentage point from April, the Labor Department said in a statement -- slightly below expectations.\n\nBut despite the small decline, inflation remains firmly above the Fed's long-term target of two percent, raising the chances that the US central bank will vote to hold rates at a 23-year high of between 5.25 and 5.50 percent later on Wednesday, and wait for additional clarity that inflation is easing.\n\nThe Fed's day of interest rate deliberations began as scheduled at 9:15am local time (1315 GMT), the Fed said in a statement.\n\n\"We expect guidance from the Fed to signal a prolonged pause as the bar for hikes or several cuts remains high,\" Bank of America economists wrote in a recent investor note.\n\n- Pushing back the cuts -\n\nThe US Fed has a dual mandate from Congress to tackle inflation and unemployment, and recent data suggest it remains broadly on track to manage both without pushing the United States into recession.\n\nWith cuts almost certainly off the agenda for this meeting, Wednesday's action is likely to center around the economic forecasts from the 19 members of the Fed's rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), which will be updated for the first time since March.\n\nAnalysts are looking to FOMC members to lower their individual forecasts for where rates will be at the end of the year in a chart known as the \"dot plot,\" bringing down the median -- or middle -- number of projected cuts this year from three down to two or fewer.\n\n\"We continue to expect the first rate cut in September,\" Goldman Sachs chief economist David Mericle wrote in a note to clients published on Sunday.\n\nHis team at Goldman sees the Fed moving to ease monetary policy every quarter after that, meaning a total of two 0.25-percentage-point cuts in 2024, and four in 2025.\n\n\"It only takes one dot moving higher to shift the median up to two 25bp (basis point) cuts -- which is our base case,\" economists at Citi wrote in a recent investor note.\n\n\"We'd be surprised to see the Fed drop two easings, but it's possible,\" economists at Pantheon Macroeconomics wrote in a note to clients on Tuesday, while also predicting the FOMC will forecast a median of two cuts this year.\n\nOther analysts, including economists at EY and Barclays, expect the updated forecasts to show a median figure of just one rate cut for 2024.\n\n\"We anticipate the dot plot of median rate expectations will feature only one 25 basis points (bps) rate cut in 2024,\" EY chief economist Gregory Daco wrote in a note to clients.\n\n- Significant shift -\n\nIf the forecasts were to show just one cut this year, it would mark a significant shift from December, when inflation appeared to be firmly on the path towards two percent, and the financial markets were preparing for as many as six rate cuts this year.\n\nFollowing Wednesday's inflation data, futures traders raised their expectations of an interest rate cut by mid-September to almost 70 percent, up sharply from around 50 percent a day earlier, according to data from CME Group.\n\nFed chair Jerome Powell has insisted in past public comments that the FOMC will remain \"data-dependent\" in its decision-making and will not be swayed by politics.\n\nNevertheless, a September start to rate cuts would almost certainly thrust the Fed into the middle of a fractious presidential campaign between President Joe Biden and his likely Republican opponent, Donald Trump, who has repeatedly questioned the US central bank's independence.\n\nda/bfm/smw/bjt/\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 Spokane"}, Not Given Confidence So Far This Year For Rate Cuts", "body": "FOMC needs to see more good data to begin cutting rates, says Jerome Powell.\n\nUS Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said Wednesday that macroeconomic data have not given Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) members confidence this year to begin rate cuts.\n\n\"The most recent inflation readings have been more favorable than earlier in the year, however, there has been modest progress toward our inflation objective,\" Powell said at a news conference after the Fed's two-day meeting concluded.\n\n\"We need to see more good data to bolster our confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward 2%,\" he added.\n\nPowell said inflation data from earlier this year were higher than expected, although more recent monthly readings have \"eased somewhat.\"\n\n\"Inflation has eased substantially from a peak of 7% to 2.7%, but it is still too high,\" he said. \"We are maintaining our restrictive stance of monetary policy in order to keep demand in line with supply, and reduce inflationary pressures.\"\n\nThe Fed chair said the labor market has come into a better balance with continued strong job gains and a low unemployment rate.\n\n\"As labor market tightness has eased and inflation has declined over the past year, the risks of reaching unemployment and inflation goals have moved towards better balance,\" he said. \"Our economy has made considerable progress towards both goals of maintaining maximum employment and stable prices.\"\n\nHe said economic activity continued to expand at a solid pace, although GDP growth moderated from 3.4% in the fourth quarter last year to 1.3% in the first quarter this year.\n\nPowell noted that the economic outlook remains uncertain, while FOMC members remain highly attentive to inflation risks.\n\n\"We know reducing policy rate too soon, or too much, could result in a reversal of the progress we have seen on inflation. At the same time, reducing policy rate too late or too little could unduly weaken economic activity and employment,\" he said.\n\n\"If the economy remains solid and inflation persists, we are prepared to maintain the current target range for the federal funds rate as long as appropriate,\" he added.\n\nThe comments came after the Fed kept its federal funds rate unchanged between the 5.25% - 5.5% target range, as widely expected, which is the highest in 23 years.\n\nThe central bank, however, signaled it expects one interest rate cut this year, according to its projection materials that were {"uri": "2024-06-386949328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "09:29:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T09:29:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T04:43:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://bilyonaryo.com/2024/06/12/us-fed-likely-to-lower-rate-cut-expectations-for-2024/money/", "title": "US Fed likely to lower rate cut expectations for 2024", "body": "The US Federal Reserve kicked off a two-day meeting to set interest rates on Tuesday, with policymakers widely expected to sit tight, and to pencil in fewer cuts for this year.\n\nThe rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) began its first day of deliberations just after 10:30am (1430 GMT), the Fed said in a statement. Its decision will be published on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nThe Fed, which has hiked rates to a 23-year high of between 5.25 and 5.50 percent, has signaled it will not begin easing monetary policy until it has more evidence that inflation is falling sustainably towards it long-term two percent target.\n\nThe recent data paint a mixed picture of stalled progress against inflation, ongoing labor market resilience, and slowing yet positive economic growth, complicating the FOMC's decision about when to start cutting.\n\nThe US central bank is almost certain to keep rates unchanged on Wednesday, and most analysts expect more Fed officials to lower the number of rate cuts they expect for this year, moving the median number of quarter percentage-point cuts from three to two or fewer.\n\nThat marks a dramatic change from December, when it seemed inflation was on a firm path towards two percent, leading the financial markets to pencil in as many as six rate cuts this year.\n\nFutures traders currently assign a probability of just over 50 percent that the Fed will make its first rate cut by September, although they see a cut by November as much more likely, according to CME Group data.\n\n\"We expect the Fed to project two cuts in 2024,\" Bank of America US economist Michael Gapen wrote in a note to clients.\n\n\"We think a majority prefers to keep optionality for September alive should inflation cooperate,\" he said.\n\nFresh consumer inflation data for May will be published early Wednesday ahead of the Fed's decision, and analysts expect the headline rate to remain Today, forecasters predict no rate cut before fall.\n\nHere's what to expect:\n\nWhat time is Fed meeting today?\n\nThe Federal Reserve is expected to announce its interest rate decision at 2 p.m. Eastern Time on Wednesday. Fed chair Jerome Powell will then hold a press conference at 2:30.\n\nInflation's sting: Will you become a more savvy shopper?\n\nPowell will likely talk about the decision and shed light on how the central bank views the overall economy. But economists and investors will be looking for clues about when the central bank finally might cut its key rate, and how many times it might do so this year.\n\nComing into the year, many economists predicted rates would already be falling. They expected as many as six or seven rate cuts this year.\n\nBut inflation endures, and at this point, most economists have scaled back their rate cut predictions to two, one or none in 2024. A few experts, including Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari, have even suggested a rate hike probably won't happen at all.\n\nInterest rates are the main tool the Fed uses to combat inflation. for this year By Investing.com", "body": "Investing.com -- The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, but signaled fewer rate cuts for this year than previously expected to ensure that monetary policy remains restrictive enough to keep the pressure on inflation.\n\nThe Federal Open Market Committee, the FOMC, kept its benchmark ratein a range of 5.25% to 5.5%.\n\nWhile the unchanged decision, the eighth in a row, was largely expected, Fed members now believe that fewer rate cuts are needed this year as the economy growth persists, while inflation remains somewhat sticky.\n\n\"Inflation has eased over the past year but remains elevated,\" the Fed said on Wednesday.\n\nFed members now see the benchmark rate falling to 5.1% this year, suggesting just one rate cut in 2024, compared with a prior estimate for three cuts.\n\nThe fresh projections arrived on the heels of the data showing that consumer inflation slowed more than expected, easing worries about {"uri": "8174864795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "19:56:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T19:56:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T19:54:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.fxstreet.com/analysis/walking-the-tightrope-the-feds-struggle-with-dual-economic-objectives-202406121850", "title": "Walking the tightrope: The Fed's struggle with dual economic objectives", "body": "The binary aspect of monetary policy is problematic. That is, monetary policy is a blunt tool that can be directed at either stimulating economic activity or suppressing it. The Federal Reserve Board, which directs this policy, has a number of mechanisms at its disposal, but essentially those tools fall under three alternative policy choices: easing monetary policy, tightening, or maintaining a neutral stance.\n\nEasing means accelerating the pace of monetary expansion with the corollary of lowering interest rates; tightening means retarding the growth of monetary expansion with rising interest rates; and taking a neutral stance allows interest rates to change because of market forces independent of Fed policy initiatives.\n\nIn theory, it's actually quite simple. Given the Fed's dual mandate to achieve price stability and full employment, the Fed is charged with responding when the economy deviates from a desired path - i.e., when either inflation or unemployment become unacceptably elevated. Tightening monetary policy would be required to rein in excessive inflation, while easing monetary policy would be needed to stimulate economic activity to bring unemployment lower. At any time, the Fed can do one or the other, but not both.\n\nStarting in early 2022 when inflation measured by year-over-year changes in consumer prices surpassed 7.5 percent, fighting inflation became the Fed's clear and obvious policy priority. Since that time, the Fed has raised its target for the Federal Funds interest rate - a key monetary policy indicator -- on 11 separate occasions with the stated goal of ultimately bringing inflation down to a pace of 2 percent per year. At its peak (June 2022), this measure of inflation reached 9.5 percent, but the latest reading (May 2024) was just 3.3 percent.\n\nThe most recent adjustment to the Fed's target for the Federal Funds rate was made in July of 2023, suggesting that, while still short of its 2 percent goal for inflation, the Fed has taken more of a neutral stance, waiting to see if its prior actions would have their effect with a lag all the while reserving the prospect for raising interest rates further if necessary - i.e., if the Fed sees inflation and/or inflationary expectations starting to move higher. It's also likely that as long as the Fed can point to at least some signs of progress on taming inflation, it can avoid raising interest rates further, hoping to continue to see inflation ebbing without pushing the economy into a recession.\n\nThese worries notwithstanding, the calculus seems to be at risk of changing with the release of the latest Department of Labor's report on job growth and unemployment rates. Despite a stronger than expected increase in jobs being created, the latest data (covering May 2024) reflect a slight uptick in the unemployment rate, coming in at 4 percent. While still low from an historical perspective, this rate had been as low as 3.4 percent during the first half of 2022.\n\nThe bind for the Fed is that it doesn't want to see inflation accelerate, nor does it want to see unemployment rates move higher; but taking any prophylactic action to mitigate either of these risks would probably exacerbate the other, leaving the Fed in the position where it will likely try to sit tight until one of these problems develops into something more concerning. The nightmare scenario is that conditions deteriorate on both fronts. Thankfully, the dilemma is not yet confronting us (or the Fed) . . . but, in time, it could.\n\nThe unanswered question is this: What are the trigger levels of inflation and/or unemployment that would cause the Fed to prioritize addressing one problem over the other? Unfortunately, it's complicated - particularly if both measures deteriorate simultaneously. Thus far, with the unemployment rate staying below 4 percent, it has been easy for the Fed to target taming inflation as its policy priority, but that policy choice will get harder if (or when) the unemployment rate becomes more elevated. Similarly, the Fed's appetite to try to reduce unemployment if that metric were to creep up would likely be compromised if a resurgence of inflationary pressures starts to develop.\n\nAdded to the mix is the reluctance that the Fed must feel about the inevitable criticism that would likely come to bear if the Fed were seen to be giving up on its commitment to bring inflation down to 2 percent. Failure to make good on that commitment could unleash inflationary expectations that have thus far been contained; and once that genie is out of the bottle, success in fighting inflation would become considerably harder. Fingers crossed.\n\nWhile some Fed observers still fault it for waiting too long to initiate its tight money policy back in 2022, my assessment is that that criticism is a cheap shot. As is the case with any time-series data (e.g., prices, interest rates, inflation rates, etc.), it's difficult to discern with any high degree of confidence whether a perturbation in the data reflects the onset of a trend or noise in the data that would soon be reversed. Given this inherent uncertainty, the Fed's reticence to commit to a policy of tightening too quickly seems eminently reasonable to me; and the Fed's commitment to be guided by additional data as they develop seems as appropriate now as it was then. Thus far, this orientation has served us well.", "source": {"uri": "fxstreet.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FXStreet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": This was slightly below expectations.\n\n\"Prices are still too high, but today's report shows welcome progress on lowering inflation,\" President Joe Biden said in a statement, after the inflation data was published.\n\nThe Republican Party, which is challenging the Democrats in November's elections, took a longer-term view of inflation, writing on X that \"prices have now risen by 20.1 per cent since Biden took office.\"\n\nAlongside its interest rate decision, the Fed also updated economic forecasts from the members of its rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC).\n\nPolicymakers lowered their individual forecasts for the number of rate cuts they expect this year, reducing the median projection for interest rates at end-2024 to the midpoint between 5.00 and 5.25 percent.\n\nThis means that FOMC participants only expect one 0.25 percentage point cut before year-end, two less than in the last update in March.\n\nFOMC participants penciled in a median of four quarter percentage-point cuts for 2025, and an additional four in 2026.\n\nAhead of the June 12 decision, many analysts had been expecting two cuts for 2024.\n\n\"We continue to expect the {"uri": "8174779994", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:38:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:38:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:37:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/fed-interest-rates-june-2024-1.7232727", "title": "U.S. Fed holds interest rates steady, sees just 1 cut in 2024 despite inflation progress | CBC News", "body": "U.S. Federal Reserve officials said Wednesday that inflation has fallen further toward their target in recent months, but signalled that they expect to cut their benchmark interest rate just once this year.\n\nThe policymakers' forecast for one rate cut was down from a previous forecast of three, likely because inflation remains persistently elevated.\n\nIn a statement issued after its two-day meeting, the Fed said that the economy is growing at a solid pace while hiring has \"remained strong.\"\n\nThe Fed also said that in recent months there has been \"modest further progress\" toward its two per cent inflation target. It's a more positive assessment than after its previous meeting May 1, when officials said there had been \"a lack of further progress\" on inflation.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Reserve", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Federal Reserve"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interest_rate", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Interest rate"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflation", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Inflation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflation_targeting", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Inflation targeting"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Arts_and_Entertainment/Amusement_Parks_and_Attractions", "label": "dmoz/Business/Arts and Entertainment/Amusement Parks and Attractions", "wgt": 10}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Picture_Ratings", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Picture Ratings", "wgt": 13}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Picture_Ratings/Automobiles", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Picture Ratings/Automobiles", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Management/Strategy_and_Forecasting", "label": "dmoz/Business/Management/Strategy and Forecasting", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Picture_Ratings/Animals", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Picture Ratings/Animals", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 48}], "image": "https://i.cbc.ca/1.6876814.1686778162!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/usa-economy-fed.JPG", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9640462", "eventUri": "eng-9640462", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-01", "textStart": 683, "textEnd": 688}], "sentiment": 0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 154, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8174741054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:06:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:06:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:04:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/companies/news/fed-holds-rates-steady-sees-just-one-cut-in-2024-despite-inflation-progress-11718215395647.html", "title": "Fed holds rates steady, sees just one cut in 2024 despite inflation progress", "body": "Policy easing hinges on more progress reducing inflation\n\nBy Howard Schneider and Ann Saphir\n\nWASHINGTON, June 12 (Reuters) - The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady on Wednesday and pushed out the start of rate cuts to perhaps as late as December, with officials projecting only a single quarter-percentage-point reduction for the year amid rising estimates for what it will take to keep inflation in check.\n\nThe markdown in the outlook for rate cuts, from three quarter-percentage-point reductions seen in the Fed's March projections, was made despite the central bank's acknowledgement in its new policy statement of \"modest further progress\" towards its 2% inflation target - an upgrade from its May 1 statement.\n\nIt coincided with an increase to 2.8% in the estimated long-run, or \"neutral,\" rate of interest, from 2.6%, which indicates policymakers have concluded the economy needs more restraint in order to finish the battle against rising prices.\n\nRecent progress has been slow, and Fed officials now project a slightly higher end-of-year inflation rate of 2.6% versus the 2.4% anticipated as of March.\n\nWhile rate cuts are now seen getting a likely later start and a slower pace this year than investors have anticipated, the Fed's policy rate is seen falling fast next year, with reductions of a full percentage point in both 2025 and 2026.\n\nThe statement and new Summary of Economic Projections show a central bank wrestling over how to respond to data that many read as pointing to slower inflation - consumer prices in fact did not rise at all in May on a month-over-month basis, according to data released on Wednesday - but also to steady growth and job creation.\n\nHIGHER NEUTRAL RATE\n\nThe new projections show the economy still expected to grow at a slightly above-trend 2.1% this year despite a sluggish first quarter, and the unemployment rate remaining at its current 4% through the year.\n\n\"Recent indicators suggest that economic activity has continued to expand at a solid pace. Job gains have remained strong, and the unemployment rate has remained low,\" the Fed said in its statement.\n\nFollowing little progress on inflation over the first months of the year, the result was a \"dot plot\" of projected policymaker interest rate forecasts that involved a near across-the-board shift higher in the rates considered needed to finish the battle against inflation.\n\nCoupled with recent debate over the possibility that the \"neutral\" rate of interest was higher than estimated, the new dot plot suggested Fed officials have concluded higher rates are needed over a longer period of time to keep inflation in check. Summed with a previous increase in the March projection, that neutral rate is now estimated at more than a quarter of a percentage point above where it ended 2023.\n\nThe Fed aggressively raised rates in 2022 and 2023 in response to a surge in inflation that peaked at a 40-year high some two years ago.\n\nFed Chair Jerome Powell will hold a press conference at 2:30 p.m. EDT (1830 GMT) to discuss the outcome of the latest meeting. (Reporting by Howard Schneider; Editing by Paul Simao)\n\nMilestone Alert! {"uri": "2024-06-387423054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:27:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:27:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T08:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.proactiveinvestors.com/companies/news/1049685/nasdaq-and-s-p-500-rally-after-inflation-boost-pre-fed-oracle-tops-leaderboard-1049685.html", "title": "Nasdaq and S&P 500 rally after inflation boost pre-Fed, Oracle tops leaderboard", "body": "US inflation slows to 3.3% in May Wall Street surges at the open Fed interest rate decision later\n\n12.05pm: Solid stock gains\n\nThe S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite index have continued to enjoy gains through the morning half of the session on Wednesday, up 1.1% and 1.8%.\n\n\"Just when all hope of a rate cut in 2024 seemed lost, today's CPI reading has provided fresh reasons to expect a cut this year,\" says Chris Beauchamp, chief market analyst at IG.\n\nThe US Fed decision is still to come in a couple of hours, and could still surprise the market.\n\n\"The past few sessions had seen stock markets hit by several blows,\" says Beauchamp, pointing to last Friday's strong jobs reading and the surprise French election, but the US morning session has seen \"a classic risk-on move - stocks are up, and the dollar and volatility are both down\".\n\n\"Today's post-CPI reaction shows there is still plenty of money prepared to get behind further gains in equities, though the Fed meeting tonight could still be a trigger for more volatility.\"\n\nThe inflation data shouldn't lead investors to expect a rate cut at the Fed's meeting later today, says Alex McGrath, chief investment officer for NorthEnd Private Wealth.\n\n\"The question for the markets now becomes is a 0.1% miss enough to justify rate cuts from our friends at the Fed? Color us skeptical on that front.\n\n\"Sure, there can be a small celebration about the progress we have made but the fact remains that three years into this cycle inflation is still running at 3.3% yoy, well above the target.\n\n\"If the goal of the Fed is to keep rates restrictive until inflation returns to target, we have many miles to go before we can rest.\"\n\n11.35am: Oracle tops the S&P leaderboard\n\nOracle is the highest riser in the S&P 500 this morning, up 10% after its AI-linked mega deals announced afterhours, which have also led to analysts upping targets this morning.\n\nDan Coatsworth, investment analyst at AJ Bell, said the news last night helped the market to \"have a new hook on which to hang the AI hype\".\n\nThe combination of Apple's AI announcements and Oracle reporting big demand for AI-related activities, \"has given investors something new to talk about and two different ways to play the theme instead of relying on chip giant Nvidia\", he said.\n\n10.30am: Favourable market conditions\n\nStrong institutional flows and a welcome slowing in US inflation have \"added to the most favourable market conditions for some time,\" says Jeff O'Connor, Liquidnet's head of market structure for the Americas.\n\n\"The optimism that has grown in recent weeks has been buoyed even further today by the increasing likelihood of rates cuts as early as September.\n\n\"While we are edging closer to the cyclical summer lull, conditions suggest that the market has the potential to move even higher.\n\n\"Heightened volumes, gains across a broad spectrum of strategies and strong hedge fund performance suggest that institutions are enjoying current market conditions. While geopolitical uncertainty hums in the background, if conditions continue to hold, we can expect institutions to continue to ride the wave - taking advantage of improving sentiment and plentiful liquidity.\"\n\n9.49am: US stocks rally at the open\n\nWall Street has rallied at the open, with today's cool inflation data boosting the hopes for a rate cut later this year.\n\nThe Dow Jones lifted by 0.8%, or 312 points, to 39,090, while the Nasdaq jumped more than 1%, 178 points, to 17,523.\n\nMeanwhile, the S&P 500 rose 0.9%, or 50 points, to 5,425.\n\nEconomists have welcomed easing inflation, arguing it will increase the likelihood of a September rate cut and drive dovish sentiment through the Federal Reserve.\n\nKathleen Brooks at XTB said: \"Heading into the CPI report it felt like the latest inflation data would determine the outcome of tonight's Fed meeting.\n\n\"The market has already priced in a dovish Fed: there is now a 65% chance of a September rate cut.\n\n\"The risk is that the market has got ahead of themselves pricing in a September rate cut. After all, the Fed will need to balance strong payroll growth alongside falling inflation when it makes its policy decision.\n\nNot only is there a 65% of a September rate cut, but the US interest rate futures market is also pricing in a 75% chance of a second cut in December.\n\n\"As we lead up to tonight's Fed meeting, the Fed will either be king maker, or the king of disappointment for traders later today.\"\n\n8.41am: US inflation cooler-than-expected\n\nUS stocks are set to open higher after inflation came in softer than expected, increasing the prospect of an interest rate cut later this year.\n\nCore inflation, which removes volatile fuel and food prices, was 3.4% for May, softening from the prior month's 3.6% rise and coming in lower than the 3.5% analysts had predicted.\n\nHeadline CPI inflation eased to 3.3% in May from April's 3.4% and beating consensus by one tenth of a percentage point.\n\nLower-than-expected inflation will prove a boost for the Federal Reserve, which is meeting today to set interest rates and has been looking for positive data to justify a cut later this year.\n\nAll three of the US's lead stock indexes are up, according to premarket futures.\n\nIt comes after both the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closed at record highs on Tuesday, with the former having been boosted by Apple reclaiming its spot as the second-largest company in the world.\n\nApple shares slipped 0.7% in pre-market trading, having closed yesterday around 7.5% higher at a new record high.", "source": {"uri": "proactiveinvestors.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8174741012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:07:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:07:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:04:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/companies/news/fed-policymakers-see-just-one-rate-cut-this-year-4-cuts-in-2025-11718215395146.html", "title": "Fed policymakers see just one rate cut this year, 4 cuts in 2025", "body": "June 12 (Reuters) - U.S. central bankers believe they'll cut interest rates just once this year, two fewer than they thought in March as inflation approaches their 2% goal more slowly than they had expected.\n\nThat's according to the median of new economic projections published on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve at the end of their June 11-12 meeting along with the widely expected decision to keep the policy rate unchanged in the 5.25%-5.5% range.\n\nBy the end of 2025, policymakers anticipate a policy rate of 4.1%, according to the median of their projections, implying an additional four quarter-of-a-percentage-point cuts next year.\n\nIn March, the last time the Fed released quarterly projections, most U.S. central bankers anticipated at least three 25 basis point rate cuts in each of 2024 and 2025. That would have put the policy rate in the 3.75%-4% range by the end of next year.\n\nA run of stronger-than-expected inflation earlier this year has forced U.S. rate-setters to recalibrate, writing down a slower start to rate cuts in the face of an economy proving more resilient than expected to the braking power of high borrowing costs.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how data released on Wednesday showing no rise in consumer prices in May from April may have factored into their forecasts.\n\nThe Fed has kept its target for the overnight bank-to-bank lending rate in its current range since last July in a bid to squeeze high inflation out of the economy without massive harm to the job market.\n\nFour Fed policymakers feel the Fed should not cut rates at all this year, the fresh projections show. Three months ago just two thought so.\n\nMeanwhile seven policymakers believe a single rate cut will be appropriate by year's end, compared with eight who believe two rate cuts will be needed.\n\nINFLATION RETHINK\n\nPolicymakers are now penciling in a fourth-quarter inflation rate of 2.6%, based on the year-over-year change in the personal consumption expenditures price index, which they target at 2%.\n\nThat's slightly higher than the 2.4% they saw in March, according to the projections, even as they expect to keep borrowing costs higher for longer. PCE inflation registered 2.7% in each of the last two months.\n\nThe forecasts are not a consensus view, but rather a midpoint of the individual expectations of the Federal Reserve's seven Washington-based governors and the 12 Fed bank presidents that is meant to offer some guidance on policymakers' thinking.\n\nCore PCE inflation - which strips out the cost of food and energy and which the Fed uses to gauge underlying price pressures - will be at 2.8% in the fourth quarter of 2024, and at 2.3% in the fourth quarter of 2025, according to the median projections.\n\nThat compares with the March median projection of 2.6% in 2024 and 2.2% in 2025.\n\nThe economic projections suggest Fed policymakers continue to expect a so-called soft landing, where the economy slows and inflation falls without a surge in joblessness.\n\nFed policymakers do see the unemployment rate, now at 4%, rising to finish 2025 at 4.2%, higher than the 4.1% they had forecast in March.\n\nThey left their forecasts for U.S. economic growth unchanged, at 2.1% this year, and 2.0% next year.\n\nFed policymakers also lifted their estimates of the longer-run neutral rate - a policy rate that neither slows nor stimulates a healthy economy - to 2.8%, from 2.6% in March and 2.5% last December. The increase may suggest that the Fed may ultimately not end up cutting rates as much as previously thought. (Reporting by Ann Saphir; Editing by Andrea Ricci)\n\nMilestone Alert! "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/money/2024/06/12/us-consumer-inflation-falls-ahead-of-fed-interest-rate-decision/139477", "title": "US consumer inflation falls ahead of Fed interest rate decision", "body": "WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Fresh US consumer inflation data published today is unlikely to sway the Federal Reserve's plans to leave its key lending rate unchanged, but could alter how many rate cuts policymakers pencil in for this year.\n\nThe annual consumer price index (CPI) came in at 3.3 per cent in May, down 0.1 percentage point from April, the Labor Department said in a statement -- slightly below expectations.\n\nBut despite the small decline, inflation remains firmly above the Fed's long-term target of two per cent, raising the chances that the US central bank will vote to hold rates at a 23-year high of between 5.25 and 5.50 percent later on tonight, and wait for additional clarity that inflation is easing.\n\nThe Fed's day of interest rate deliberations began as scheduled at 9.15am local time (9.15pm Malaysian time), the Fed said in a statement.\n\n\"We expect guidance from the Fed to signal a prolonged pause as the bar for hikes or several cuts remains high,\" Bank of America economists wrote in a recent investor note.\n\nPushing back the cuts\n\nThe US Fed has a dual mandate from Congress to tackle inflation and unemployment, and recent data suggest it remains broadly on track to manage both without pushing the United States into recession.\n\nWith cuts almost certainly off the agenda for this meeting, Wednesday's action is likely to centre around the economic forecasts from the 19 members of the Fed's rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), which will be updated for the first time since March.\n\nAnalysts are looking to FOMC members to lower their individual forecasts for where rates will be at the end of the year in a chart known as the \"dot plot,\" bringing down the median -- or middle -- number of projected cuts this year from three down to two or fewer.\n\n\"We continue to expect the first rate cut in September,\" Goldman Sachs chief economist David Mericle wrote in a note to clients published on Sunday.\n\nHis team at Goldman sees the Fed moving to ease monetary policy every quarter after that, meaning a total of two 0.25-percentage-point cuts in 2024, and four in 2025.\n\n\"It only takes one dot moving higher to shift the median up to two 25bp (basis point) cuts -- which is our base case,\" economists at Citi wrote in a recent investor note.\n\n\"We'd be surprised to see the Fed drop two easings, but it's possible,\" economists at Pantheon Macroeconomics wrote in a note to clients on Tuesday, while also predicting the FOMC will forecast a median of two cuts this year.\n\nOther analysts, including economists at EY and Barclays, expect the updated forecasts to show a median figure of just one rate cut for 2024.\n\n\"We anticipate the dot plot of median rate expectations will feature only one 25 basis points (bps) rate cut in 2024,\" EY chief economist Gregory Daco wrote in a note to clients.\n\nSignificant shift\n\nIf the forecasts were to show just one cut this year, it would mark a significant shift from December, when inflation appeared to be firmly on the path towards two per cent, and the financial markets were preparing for as many as six rate cuts this year.\n\nFollowing Wednesday's inflation data, futures traders raised their expectations of an interest rate cut by mid-September to almost 70 per cent, up sharply from around 50 per cent a day earlier, according to data from CME Group.\n\nFed chair Jerome Powell has insisted in past public comments that the FOMC will remain \"data-dependent\" in its decision-making and will not be swayed by politics.\n\nNevertheless, a September start to rate cuts would almost certainly thrust the Fed into the middle of a fractious presidential campaign between President Joe Biden and his likely Republican opponent, Donald Trump, who has repeatedly questioned the US central bank's independence. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "malaymail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-06-387519726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:15:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:15:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:07:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.cityam.com/fed-holds-interest-rates-for-seventh-consecutive-meeting-after-modest-progress-on-inflation/", "title": "Fed holds interest rates after 'modest' progress on inflation", "body": "The US Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates on hold for the seventh consecutive meeting but surprised markets with projections which showed that policymakers expect to cut interest rates only once in 2024.\n\nThe rate decision was widely expected and means that the federal funds rate remains in a range of 5.25-5.50 per cent, a level reached last July.\n\nThe Fed said that there has only been \"modest further progress\" towards the two per cent target, cautioning that inflation \"remains elevated\".\n\nAlongside its latest decision, the Fed released its latest set of 'dot-plot' projections which showed that policymakers only expect to cut rates once this year, down from three back in March.\n\nThis reflected higher inflation forecasts. Rate-setters revised up their median expectation on core personal consumption expenditure (PCE) over the year to 2.8 per cent from 2.6 per cent. Core PCE is the Fed's preferred gauge of inflation.\n\nThe decision came just a few hours after the latest inflation data for May, which showed inflation slightly undershot expectations.\n\nPrices were unchanged in May for the first time since last June, compared to the 0.1 per cent increase expected by economists. This brought the headline rate down to 3.3 per cent.\n\nCore inflation also came in lower than expected, rising just 0.2 per cent on last month. This was the slowest rate of increase since August 2021.\n\nLooking back over this year, however, inflation has remained frustratingly persistent, forcing markets to reassess when the rate cutting cycle will begin. At the turn of the year investors thought the cutting cycle would be well underway but now traders do not expect a cut until September.\n\nAlthough there are some signs the economy is beginning to weaken under the pressure of the Fed's rate hikes, it remains too strong to be confident that inflation will remain sustainably at two per cent.\n\nFigures out last week showed that the economy added significantly more jobs than expected in April. The Fed noted that \"job gains have remained strong and the unemployment rate has remained low\".\n\nThe decision comes a week after the European Central Bank (ECB) voted to cut interest rates for the first time in five years, reflecting the underlying weakness of the European economy. This decision comes amid rising estimates for the measures needed to curb inflation, with Fed officials projecting only a single rate cut for 2024. This marks a shift from the three cuts anticipated in March, despite acknowledging \"modest further progress\" towards the 2% inflation target. This adjustment removes the likelihood of a rate cut before the U.S. presidential election on November 5.\n\nStocks held gains immediately after the Fed's statement and updated projections, while the U.S. dollar and Treasury yields pared losses. Traders continue to price in a September start to policy easing, expecting a second cut by year-end. However, the Fed's slower approach indicates a more cautious stance, reflecting the ongoing challenge of balancing economic growth with inflation control. The policy rate is expected to decrease by a full percentage point in both 2025 and 2026.\n\nThe new projections suggest that Fed officials are wrestling with mixed economic signals. Despite no month-over-month rise in consumer prices for May, the economy continues to show steady growth and job creation. The central bank's statement indicates that higher rates may be necessary for a longer period to fully address inflation, reflecting a significant policy adjustment.\n\nFed Chair Jerome Powell will provide further insights during his press conference at 2:30 p.m. EDT, discussing the outcome of the two-day meeting and elaborating on the Fed's strategy to manage economic stability and inflation AP\n\nThe Fed voted unanimously to maintain its benchmark interest rate between 5.25 and 5.50 percent, and said in a statement that \"modest\" progress had been made toward its long-term inflation target of two percent.\n\nThe announcement suggests that central bank officials remain wary about cutting rates too soon, despite consumer inflation data published earlier Wednesday, which pointed to a slowdown in the rate of price increases in May.\n\nThe annual consumer price index (CPI) came in at 3.3 percent last month, down 0.1 percentage point from April and unchanged on a monthly basis, the Labor Department said. This was slightly below expectations.\n\nAlongside its interest rate decision, the Fed also updated economic forecasts from the members of its rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC).\n\nPolicymakers lowered their individual forecasts for the number of rate cuts they expect this year, reducing the median projection for interest rates at end-2024 to the midpoint between 4.50 and 4.75.\n\nThis means that FOMC participants only expect one 0.25 percentage point cut before year-end, two less than in the last update in March.\n\nFed officials also raised their inflation {"uri": "8174429333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "14:24:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T14:24:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T14:23:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/us-consumer-inflation-falls-ahead-of-fed-interest-rate-decision/article_e56fdf90-17a3-5ab9-9155-8db27c341826.html", "title": "US consumer inflation falls ahead of Fed interest rate decision", "body": "Back in March, FOMC members penciled in a median of 0.75 percentage points of rate cuts this year\n\nFresh US consumer inflation data published Wednesday is unlikely to sway the Federal Reserve's plans to leave its key lending rate unchanged, but could alter how many rate cuts policymakers pencil in for this year.\n\nThe annual consumer price index (CPI) came in at 3.3 percent in May, down 0.1 percentage point from April, the Labor Department said in a statement -- slightly below expectations.\n\nBut despite the small decline, inflation remains firmly above the Fed's long-term target of two percent, raising the chances that the US central bank will vote to hold rates at a 23-year high of between 5.25 and 5.50 percent later on Wednesday, and wait for additional clarity that inflation is easing.\n\nThe Fed's day of interest rate deliberations began as scheduled at 9:15am local time (1315 GMT), the Fed said in a statement.\n\n\"We expect guidance from the Fed to signal a prolonged pause as the bar for hikes or several cuts remains high,\" Bank of America economists wrote in a recent investor note.\n\n- Pushing back the cuts -\n\nThe US Fed has a dual mandate from Congress to tackle inflation and unemployment, and recent data suggest it remains broadly on track to manage both without pushing the United States into recession.\n\nWith cuts almost certainly off the agenda for this meeting, Wednesday's action is likely to center around the economic forecasts from the 19 members of the Fed's rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), which will be updated for the first time since March.\n\nAnalysts are looking to FOMC members to lower their individual forecasts for where rates will be at the end of the year in a chart known as the \"dot plot,\" bringing down the median -- or middle -- number of projected cuts this year from three down to two or fewer.\n\n\"We continue to expect the first rate cut in September,\" Goldman Sachs chief economist David Mericle wrote in a note to clients published on Sunday.\n\nHis team at Goldman sees the Fed moving to ease monetary policy every quarter after that, meaning a total of two 0.25-percentage-point cuts in 2024, and four in 2025.\n\n\"It only takes one dot moving higher to shift the median up to two 25bp (basis point) cuts -- which is our base case,\" economists at Citi wrote in a recent investor note.\n\n\"We'd be surprised to see the Fed drop two easings, but it's possible,\" economists at Pantheon Macroeconomics wrote in a note to clients on Tuesday, while also predicting the FOMC will forecast a median of two cuts this year.\n\nOther analysts, including economists at EY and Barclays, expect the updated forecasts to show a median figure of just one rate cut for 2024.\n\n\"We anticipate the dot plot of median rate expectations will feature only one 25 basis points (bps) rate cut in 2024,\" EY chief economist Gregory Daco wrote in a note to clients.\n\n- Significant shift -\n\nIf the forecasts were to show just one cut this year, it would mark a significant shift from December, when inflation appeared to be firmly on the path towards two percent, and the financial markets were preparing for as many as six rate cuts this year.\n\nFollowing Wednesday's inflation data, futures traders raised their expectations of an interest rate cut by mid-September to almost 70 percent, up sharply from around 50 percent a day earlier, according to data from CME Group.\n\nFed chair Jerome Powell has insisted in past public comments that the FOMC will remain \"data-dependent\" in its decision-making and will not be swayed by politics.\n\nNevertheless, a September start to rate cuts would almost certainly thrust the Fed into the middle of a fractious presidential campaign between President Joe Biden and his likely Republican opponent, Donald Trump, who has repeatedly questioned the US central bank's independence.\n\nda/bfm/smw/bjt/", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "daniel_avis@ktbs.com", "name": "Daniel Avis", "type": "author", "isAgency": Consumer prices fell below economists' expectations for the second month in a row.\n\nInflation was flat last month and was up 3.3% year-over-year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported, a data point that could put the Federal Reserve back on track to ease its policy later this year after a series of discouraging inflation reports in the first quarter.\n\nThree rate cuts by the end of 2024 are back on the table, with investors seeing a 72% chance the Fed could cut rates three times or more by December, according to the CME FedWatch Tool.\n\nSome Wall Street analysts predict the Fed's first cut could come as soon as July, though most see a rate cut in September as the most likely scenario.\n\n\"Wednesday's weaker-than-expected CPI will allow the Fed to start cutting interest rates as soon as September, since we have now seen multiple encouraging inflation readings, after the concerning spike in inflation earlier this year,\" Skyler Weinand, the chief investment officer of Regan Capital, said in a note. \"There's a clear path to a soft landing and the Fed may very well be coming to the market's rescue in as little as three months.\"\n\n\"Today's news would seem to open the door to a July rate cut, although we still think that's very unlikely given hawkish rhetoric from the Fed recently,\" Preston Caldwell, Morningstar's chief US economist said in a statement. \"But rate cuts starting by September should now be cemented as overwhelming likely.\"\n\nHeadline inflation has eased, partly due to cooling gas and food prices. BLS data shows that the gas index slumped 3.6% in May. Meanwhile, the food at home index remained level after dropping 0.2% in April.\n\n\"The Fed is increasingly risking a downturn in the economy by leaving rates too high for too long,\" Ryan Severino, the chief economist for BGO said on Wednesday. \"While our modeling suggests that the Fed could cut later this year, it does not have infinite time on its hands, especially as we see more evidence of slowing in the US economy.\"\n\nInvestors are waiting for Fed Chair Jerome Powell to speak later this afternoon, which should give markets more guidance on the path of rate cuts. But the chief central banker will likely hold off on rate cut signals for now, Weinand said, thanks to hotter-than-expected inflation prints all throughout the first quarter.\n\n\"Things are playing out as the Fed hoped, so Jerome Powell will probably be feeling good this afternoon,\" David Russell, TradeStation's global head of market strategy, said in a note. \"The bears have nowhere to run to {"uri": "8174649034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:58:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:58:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:52:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/business/stock-markets-jump-as-us-inflation-cools-wit-1834811.html", "title": "Stock Markets Jump As US Inflation Cools, With Eyes On Fed - UrduPoint", "body": "Stock markets surged Wednesday after data showed US inflation slowed in May, raising hopes the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates later this year\n\nLondon, (UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 12th Jun, 2024) Stock markets surged Wednesday after data showed US inflation slowed in May, raising hopes the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates later this year.\n\nWall Street's tech-heavy Nasdaq and broad-based S&P 500 extended gains in afternoon deals rallied to fresh records the previous day.\n\nEuropean markets closed sharply higher after falling earlier this week in the wake of the far-right's strong performance in the elections to the EU Parliament.\n\nThe dollar fell against other major currencies as lower rates make the greenback less attractive.\n\nThe Fed is widely expected to keep rates unchanged at the end of a regular monetary policy meeting later Wednesday, but markets are keenly awaiting its \"dot plot\" guidance, which shows its outlook for rates this year.\n\nThe spotlight will also be on Fed chief Jerome Powell as investors listen for any other signals about the central bank's plans during his press conference following the meeting.\n\nThe drop in consumer inflation was welcomed by traders who have worried that the Fed may introduce fewer rate cuts -- or none at all -- than previously thought this year.\n\n\"The cool inflation numbers should boost investor confidence for a Fed rate cut in the second half of 2024,\" said Bret Kenwell, US investment analyst at trading platform eToro.\n\n\"But will the Fed throw gasoline or cold water on the fire when it comes to rate cuts?\"\n\nThe annual consumer price index (CPI) came in at 3.3 percent in May, down 0.1 percentage point from April, the Labor Department said.\n\nWith inflation slowing and other recent data showing signs the US economy is cooling, the market is pricing in two rates cuts by the end of the year, Kenwell said.\n\n- Macron 'calms' markets -\n\nForecasts for the number of reductions the Fed will make in 2024 have been whittled down from six at the start of the year following a string of figures indicating the US labour market remains solid and the economy remains resilient.\n\n\"This confuses the outlook for the US economy: jobs growth is strong, yet inflation is moderating,\" said Kathleen Brooks, research director at trading platform XTB.\n\n\"What should the Fed do in this situation? If the market reaction is anything to go by, then the Fed will be dovish later on this evening when they announce their latest policy report.\"\n\nThe US inflation figure was \"also giving European stocks a chance to recover\", she added.\n\nShe said the markets were also \"calmed\" by a commitment by French President Emmanuel Macron that he would not resign on the outcome of snap legislative eyes on Fed", "body": "Stock markets surged Wednesday after data showed US inflation slowed in May, raising hopes the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates later this year.\n\nWall Street's main indices opened higher following records the previous day while European markets rebounded after falling earlier this week following the far-right's strong performance in EU Parliament elections.\n\nThe dollar fell against other major currencies as lower rates make the greenback less attractive.\n\nThe Fed is widely expected to keep rates unchanged at the end of a regular monetary policy meeting later Wednesday, but markets are keenly awaiting its \"dot plot\" guidance, which shows its outlook for rates this year.\n\nThe spotlight will also fall on Fed chief Jerome Powell as investors will listen for any hints about the central bank's plans during his conference following the meeting.\n\nThe drop in consumer inflation was welcomed by traders who have worried that the Fed may introduce fewer rate cuts -- or none at all -- than previously thought this year.\n\n\"The cool inflation numbers should boost investor confidence for a Fed rate cut in the second half of 2024,\" said Bret Kenwell, US investment analyst at trading platform eToro.\n\n\"But will the Fed throw gasoline or cold water on the fire when it comes to rate cuts?\"\n\nThe annual consumer price index (CPI) came in at 3.3 percent in May, down 0.1 percentage point from April, the Labor Department said.\n\nWith inflation slowing and other recent data showing signs the US economy is cooling, the market is pricing in two rates cuts by the end of the year, Kenwell said.\n\nForecasts for the number of reductions the Fed will make in 2024 have been whittled down from six at the start of the year following a string of figures indicating the US labour market remains solid and the economy remains resilient.\n\n\"This confuses the outlook for the US economy: jobs growth is strong, yet inflation is moderating,\" said Kathleen Brooks, research director at trading platform XTB.\n\n\"What should the Fed do in this situation? stocks a chance to recover\", she added.\n\nShe said the markets were \"calmed\" by a commitment by French President Emmanuel Macron that he would not resign on the outcome of the snap legislative Job gains have remained strong, and the unemployment rate has remained low,\" the Fed said in its statement.\n\nFollowing little progress on inflation over the first months of the year, the result was a \"dot plot\" of projected policymaker interest rate forecasts that involved a near across-the-board shift higher in the rates considered needed to finish the battle against inflation.\n\nSummed with a previous increase in the March projection, that neutral rate is now estimated at more than a quarter of a percentage point above where it ended 2023.\n\nCoupled with recent debate over the possibility that the \"neutral\" rate of interest was higher than estimated, the new dot plot suggested Fed officials have concluded higher rates are needed over a longer period of time to keep This was slightly below expectations.\n\nAlongside its interest rate decision, the Fed also updated economic forecasts from the members of its rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC).\n\nPolicymakers lowered their individual forecasts for the number of rate cuts they expect this year, reducing the median projection for interest rates at end-2024 to the midpoint between 4.50 "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/us-inflation-data-unlikely-to-alter-fed-plans-to-hold-rates-steady/article_e79b3955-fd8c-5ba2-a9eb-5b75668e5133.html", "title": "US inflation data unlikely to alter Fed plans to hold rates steady", "body": "Back in March, FOMC members penciled in a median of 0.75 percentage-points of rate cuts this year\n\nFresh US consumer inflation data published Wednesday is unlikely to sway the Federal Reserve, which is widely expected to leave its key lending rate unchanged and lower the number of cuts it has penciled in for this year.\n\nThe May headline consumer inflation rate is expected to be little changed from a month earlier, according to the median forecast of economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.\n\nIf the analysts are correct, inflation will remain stuck firmly above the Fed's long-term target of two percent, giving the US central bank an additional incentive to hold rates at a 23-year high of between 5.25 and 5.50 percent, and wait for the economic winds to change.\n\n\"We expect guidance from the Fed to signal a prolonged pause as the bar for hikes or several cuts remains high,\" Bank of America economists wrote in a recent investor note.\n\n- Pushing back the cuts -\n\nThe US Fed has a dual mandate from Congress to tackle both inflation and unemployment, and the data suggests it remains broadly on track to tackle both without pushing the US into recession -- despite the small uptick in headline inflation in the first few months of this year.\n\nWith cuts almost certainly off the agenda for this meeting, Wednesday's action is likely to center around the economic forecasts from the 19 members of the Fed's rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), which will be updated for the first time since March.\n\nAnalysts are looking to FOMC members to lower their individual forecasts for where rates will be at the end of the year in a chart known as the \"dot plot,\" which reduces the median number of projected cuts this year from three down to two or fewer.\n\n\"We continue to expect the first rate cut in September,\" Goldman Sachs chief economist David Mericle wrote in a note to clients published on Sunday.\n\nHis team at Goldman sees the Fed moving to ease monetary policy every quarter after that, meaning a total of two 0.25-percentage-point cuts in 2024, and four in 2025.\n\n\"It only takes one dot moving higher to shift the median up to two 25bp (basis point) cuts -- which is our base case,\" economists at Citi wrote in a recent investor note.\n\nMore from this section Sachem School Board meeting for first time since adopting new proposed budget CA: 84th Annual Peabody Awards - Arrivals - 53821890 Apple Announces AI Program, Partnership With OpenAI - TaiwanPlus News\n\n\"We'd be surprised to see the Fed drop two easings, but it's possible,\" economists at Pantheon Macroeconomics wrote in a note to clients on Tuesday, while also predicting the FOMC will forecast a median of two cuts this year.\n\nOther analysts, including economists at EY and Barclays, expect the updated forecasts to show a median figure of just one rate cut for 2024.\n\n\"We anticipate the dot plot of median rate expectations will feature only one 25 basis points (bps) rate cut in 2024,\" EY chief economist Gregory Daco wrote in a note to clients.\n\n- Significant shift -\n\nIf the forecasts were to show just one cut this year, it would mark a significant shift from December, when inflation appeared to be firmly on the path towards two percent, and the financial markets were preparing for as many as six rate cuts this year.\n\nBy contrast, futures traders currently assign a probability of just over 50 percent that the Fed will make its first rate cut by September, although they see November as much more likely, according to data from CME Group.\n\nShortly after the interest rate decision is announced, Fed chair Jerome Powell will take questions from reporters during a press conference in Washington.\n\nPowell has insisted in past public comments that the FOMC will remain \"data-dependent\" in its decision-making, and will not be swayed by politics.\n\nNevertheless, a September start to rate cuts would almost certainly thrust the Fed into the middle of a fractious presidential campaign between President Joe Biden and his Republican opponent, Donald Trump, who has repeatedly questioned the US central bank's independence.\n\nda/bfm/smw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news",
